{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3556908,"name":"","username":"Mateo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/f4b2a3/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T13:10:36.913Z","cooked":"

I guess I’m kinda confused about how to use pathplanner, as when I’ve tried it, my robot just shoots across the field? My path was created on the red side and when starting my robot was not in the correct starting position, but I assumed it did not matter. How do I setup to test pathplanner? Code: GitHub - Mateo-Johnson/swerg

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-03-14T13:10:36.913Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":113,"readers_count":112,"score":92.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495555,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-makes-the-robot-shoot-across-the-field","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://github.com/Mateo-Johnson/swerg","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"GitHub - Mateo-Johnson/swerg","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58360,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-makes-the-robot-shoot-across-the-field/495555/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3556937,"name":"Aidan","username":"FieryFuryGame","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fieryfurygame/{size}/262141_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-14T13:47:04.184Z","cooked":"

The AutoBuilder is set to flip any auto to the other side of the field when the robot is on the red alliance. (So if the path is set on the blue alliance side, it will still work on the red alliance side)

I believe PathPlanner also tries to make sure the robot’s starting position is correct. Because the path is flipping from the red side to the blue side, the robot tries to go to that starting position on the blue side.

I would try putting all of your autos and paths on the blue alliance side, and then everything should work correctly.

The PathPlanner app also has a telemetry tab, which could help you see what PathPlanner is thinking at a given moment, and where it wants the robot to go.

I hope this helps!

as @FieryFuryGame mentioned, pathplanner automatically flips the path to be correct for whichever side of the field you are on. if you have vision with pose estimation, your starting position being just a little off will not matter, and pathplanner will use PID to correct it, however if you are not using vision you should try to be as exact as possible with your positioning of the robot starting position.

Try implementing a SwerveDrivePoseEstimator instead of a SwerveDriveOdometry. You can find the documentation here SwerveDrivePoseEstimator (WPILib API 2025.3.1). Once you implement the SwerveDrivePoseEstimator, you can just call addVisionMeasurement() to add the results from your camera.

Secondary question, should I be turning the robot on and moving it to the starting position or putting it into the starting position then turning on?

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-03-15T22:34:44.708Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":27,"readers_count":26,"score":10.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":495555,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-makes-the-robot-shoot-across-the-field","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":74068,"username":"FieryFuryGame","name":"Aidan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fieryfurygame/{size}/262141_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58360,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-makes-the-robot-shoot-across-the-field/495555/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3557937,"name":"Aidan","username":"FieryFuryGame","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fieryfurygame/{size}/262141_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-15T23:38:45.634Z","cooked":"

I don’t have a clear answer, but I can tell you what I’ve been doing for our robot. Overall, find what works best for you though.

I personally like to drive the robot to the starting position while testing, but then power-cycle to make sure the auto is accurate to how it would be during competition. We have vision, so the starting position being super accurate isn’t a major concern. Without vision, I would drive over, and then try to position manually.

During practice, we might let the two people moving the robot onto the field during the event practice battery replacement, robot positioning, and other things. I’m not sure on this though.

I’m not an expert on this (this is my second year), so there’s probably a better answer to your question than I have.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2025-03-16T01:27:57.415Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":13,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":18,"readers_count":17,"score":8.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":495555,"topic_slug":"pathplanner-makes-the-robot-shoot-across-the-field","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":74068,"username":"FieryFuryGame","name":"Aidan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fieryfurygame/{size}/262141_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58360,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/pathplanner-makes-the-robot-shoot-across-the-field/495555/15","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3558023,"name":"Aidan","username":"FieryFuryGame","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fieryfurygame/{size}/262141_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-16T01:49:57.616Z","cooked":"

The telemetry tab in PathPlanner, when running a path or auto, can tell you how closely the path is being followed. If the actual driving is decently changed from the goal, then tune it.

Telemetry | PathPlanner Docs

(Hopefully this link works)

You can also make a path to go in a straight line, and mark the start and end of the path with tape or another marker. Then just see how close the robot is to going that set distance when running the path. I haven’t made sure of this, but you may want to make sure the path long enough that the robot accelerates to the velocity you have set. Our robot went around the correct distance immediately, so I can’t verify this method.

Again, I’m not an expert on PathPlanner or programming or anything like this, so take my thoughts as an idea, rather than the best way of doing things. This is from my limited experience. There are probably a lot of other Chief Delphi threads that have much better answers.
